conclusion: There are four containers at the top labeled A, B, C, and D, and three containers at the bottom labeled E, F, and G. Between them are several angled barriers/baffles (black, yellow, white, and gray strips). The liquid needs to navigate these barriers to reach the bottom containers.
Container A is light teal, container B is yellow, container C is blue, and container D is white. Container E is green, container F is red, and container G is white.
The black baffle is slanted downward to the left, the yellow baffle is slanted downward to the right, the white baffle is horizontal, and the gray baffle is slanted downward to the left.

premise: Liquid from container A flows downward and hits the black baffle, which redirects it to the left.
conclusion: The liquid from container A collects on the left side of the board.

premise: The liquid from container A collects on the left side of the board.
conclusion: The liquid from container A reaches container E.

premise: Liquid from container B flows downward and hits the yellow diagonal baffle, which redirects it along the baffle.
conclusion: The liquid from container B encounters the white horizontal baffle and is redirected.

premise: The liquid from container B encounters the white horizontal baffle and is redirected.
conclusion: The liquid from container B reaches container F.

premise: Liquid from container C flows downward and follows the gray baffle.
conclusion: The liquid from container C mixes with some white liquid and continues downward.

premise: The liquid from container C mixes with some white liquid and continues downward.
conclusion: The liquid from container C reaches container G.

premise: Liquid from container D flows directly downward without hitting any baffles initially.
conclusion: The liquid from container D branches into two paths.

premise: The liquid from container D branches into two paths.
conclusion: Some of the liquid from container D mixes with the liquid from container C and reaches container G.

premise: The liquid from container D branches into two paths.
conclusion: The main flow of liquid from container D reaches container G.

premise: Liquid from container A flows to container E, liquid from container B flows to container F, liquid from container C flows to container G, and liquid from container D flows to container G.
conclusion: All the streams mix up and end in containers E and F; container F has a higher liquid level than container E; container G has the majority of stream D and some droplets of stream C.
